(Thousands of United States dollars)
Regional coordination

The regional teams of the resident coordinator system provide support for country-level coordination. They focus on day-to-day management and support for coherent and effective delivery of operational activities for development by resident coordinators and United Nations country teams through integrated policy programming and operational support, together with the regional teams of the United Nations Sustainable Development Group and the United Nations regional economic and social commissions. The regional offices of the Development Coordination Office are strategically positioned to provide tailored and dedicated support to various regions around the world, due to their close proximity to the point of delivery and direct oversight of a select number of country contexts. There is no change in number and level of posts in 2026 compared with 2025.
The distribution of resources for regional coordination is reflected in tables 1.161 and 1.162.

(Thousands of United States dollars/number of posts)

Country coordination

Country coordination consists of the work that resident coordinators undertake with the support of resident coordinator offices in leading a new generation of United Nations country teams and development system support for the implementation of the 2030 Agenda at the country level. This independent, impartial and empowered coordination function operates in full alignment with national priorities, needs and planning frameworks under the ownership and leadership of programme countries, for a coherent, effective, efficient and accountable response to country-specific needs, to maximize the impact of the United Nations support and the sustainability of development results. The proposed staffing for 2026 includes an upward reclassification of the resident coordinator post in Nigeria from D-2 to Assistant Secretary-General level; an increase of one post at the Assistant Secretary-General level in Somalia for the Resident Coordinator and Humanitarian Coordinator function beginning November 2026, following the anticipated closure of the United Nations Transitional Assistance Mission in Somalia; and an increase of one post at the D-2 level in Iraq for the Resident Coordinator and Humanitarian Coordinator function, following the closure of the United Nations Assistance Mission in Iraq from September 2026. Previously, the Resident Coordinator and Humanitarian Coordinator posts in Iraq and Somalia were reflected as cost-shared triple-hatted Deputy Special Representative of the Secretary-General/Resident Coordinator/Humanitarian Coordinator (DSRSG/RC/HC) posts.

The distribution of resources for country coordination is reflected in tables 1.163 and 1.164 (a) for resources under the special purpose trust fund and in table 1.164 (b) for resources under locally mobilized resources.

Programme support

Programme support services are provided by the Resident Coordinator System Business Management Branch in the Development Coordination Office, with the overall objective of managing the operations of the resident coordinator system to ensure full accountability for and oversight of the system. The Branch serves as the Executive Office of the Development Coordination Office and provides daily business services and administrative support to the Office at the global level, including on human resources, information technology, finance, travel, procurement and systems platform management. It is responsible for the development and oversight of and reporting on the Office’s headquarters budget. The Branch manages the operational relationship with the service providers of the resident coordinator system. It advises and provides backstopping support on business services to the Office’s regional desks and resident coordinator offices. It coordinates and oversees resident coordinator system results-based budgeting and regular reporting, including to the General Assembly. It is responsible for financial management and financial reporting on all sources of funds for the resident coordinator system. The Branch is also responsible for policy guidance on management accountability and oversight support for the Office in coordination with other offices within the Secretariat. There is no change in number and level of posts in 2026 compared with 2025.

text: XIV.	United Nations Youth Office

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The United Nations has long recognized that the imagination, ideals and energy of young people are vital for the continuing development of the societies in which they live. In 1965, in its resolution 2037 (XX), the General Assembly acknowledged the Declaration on the Promotion among Youth of the Ideals of Peace, Mutual Respect and Understanding between Peoples. In 1995, the Assembly adopted the World Programme of Action for Youth to the Year 2000 and Beyond in its resolution 50/81, which provided a policy framework and practical guidelines to improve the situation of young people. In 2007, the Assembly adopted the Supplement to the Word Programme of Action for Youth to the Year 2000 and Beyond in its resolution 62/126, which provided further guidance on promoting the participation of young people in social and economic development. Since 2015, the Security Council, in its resolutions 2250 (2015), 2419 (2018) and 2535 (2020), has called upon all relevant actors to increase the inclusive representation of young people in the prevention and resolution of conflict, including when negotiating and implementing peace agreements.

In 2013, the Secretary-General appointed the first Envoy on Youth. In 2018, to strengthen the coordination and accountability of the United Nations system with regard to its work on young people, the Secretary-General launched the United Nations Youth Strategy. The General Assembly, in its resolution 76/306, decided to establish the United Nations Youth Office as a dedicated office for youth affairs in the Secretariat, integrating the Office of the Secretary-General’s Envoy on Youth. On 27 October 2023, the Secretary-General appointed the first-ever Assistant Secretary-General for Youth Affairs to lead the Office, representing the youngest serving Assistant Secretary-General in the history of the Organization. The mandate derives from the priorities established in relevant resolutions and decisions of the Assembly and the Security Council, including Assembly resolutions 50/81, 62/126, 76/306, 77/336 and 78/179 and Council resolutions 2250 (2015), 2419 (2018) and 2535 (2020).
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this programme contributes, is to ensure the meaningful engagement and leadership of young people in the work of the United Nations and accelerated action at the global, regional and country levels to empower young people, to promote their rights and address their needs.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Office will:

(a)	Lead engagement and advocacy for the advancement of youth issues across the United Nations in the areas of peace and security, sustainable development and human rights, through engagement with Member State representatives, principals of United Nations organs and senior management of United Nations entities, and in close consultation with young people;

(b)	Promote meaningful, inclusive and effective engagement of young people and of youth-led and youth-focused organizations in the work of the United Nations, in close collaboration with United Nations system entities;

(c)	Encourage greater United Nations system-wide collaboration, coordination and accountability on the advancement of youth issues, including United Nations support to Member States, as appropriate and upon request, in promoting the effective and meaningful engagement, participation and empowerment of young people;
(d)	Engage with youth-focused envoys, representatives and offices of regional organizations on advancing youth issues;

(e)	Propose innovative approaches to advance multi-stakeholder initiatives on the engagement and empowerment of young people, for the consideration of Member States, including on quality and inclusive education, decent jobs, skills development, digital transformation and youth-led innovation and solutions;

(f)	Promote and facilitate intergenerational and intercultural dialogue, collaboration and solidarity by creating opportunities for young people to not only share and collaborate among one other, but also engage with Member States, the private sector, academia and the United Nations, including through intergovernmental policy forums;

(g)	Support efforts to enhance youth representation at the United Nations, including through increasing and improving the conditions of internships and employment opportunities for young people, especially for those from developing countries and with due regard to gender balance;

(h)	Support efforts towards the mobilization of financial and technical support and investment to promote and upscale quality and inclusive education and training, skills development, capacity-building and bridging the digital divide, in tandem with job creation, for young people and creating an enabling environment for harnessing their talents and abilities to contribute to their societies;

(i)	Conduct outreach to young people and to youth-led and youth-focused organizations, through innovative means, including the use of social media, narrative storytelling and audiovisual content, with an emphasis on the creation of multilingual assets and templates, where possible, for global dissemination through United Nations country teams and United Nations information centres.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a) 	Meaningful youth engagement systematically integrated into governance structures, policymaking, and decision-making processes at intergovernmental, regional, national, levels;
(b)	Strengthened coherence, accountability and collaboration on youth issues across the UN system;

(c)	Enhanced mechanisms and increased investments made available to support socio-economic opportunities for youth, across social, economic, and environmental priorities at global, regional, and national levels.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Member States continue to support the advancement of the situation of young people, including in the implementation of relevant international frameworks and agreements;
(b)	Sustained recognition by the global community of the important role that young people play in the promotion of peace and security, sustainable development and human rights;
(c)	There is adequate allocation of resources for action on young people and meaningful youth engagement across the United Nations system, national, regional and global institutions.

With regard to cooperation with other entities at the global, regional, national and local levels, the Office will collaborate with regional and national youth envoys and regional organizations. It will also prioritize the forging of new relationships and the strengthening of existing ones with relevant youth organizations, civil society organizations, academia and the private sector.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Office will continue to mobilize United Nations entities and United Nations country teams for improved coordination, collaboration and accountability on youth work across the United Nations system. It will collaborate with the Department of Global Communications and other United Nations entities through management of a dedicated youth-focused communications group. It will also work with the Department of Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance, the Department of Operational Support and other members of the Strategy task team to improve internships and employment opportunities across the United Nations system. It will partner with relevant UN entities, as mandated, on meaningful youth participation in major intergovernmental meetings, and other UN agencies, funds and programmes to promote socio-economic opportunities for young people and reduce the digital divide. As part of the efforts to strengthen the youth, peace and security agenda, the Office will continue its collaboration with the Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs and the United Nations Population Fund, as well as with OHCHR and other relevant entities on young people’s political participation and protection issues. The Office will also contribute regularly to the work of various inter-agency working groups and will provide secretariat support to the inter-agency high-level steering committee and joint working group responsible for advancing coherent action by the United Nations system on youth-related matters.

The Office integrates a gender perspective into its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate, by ensuring the meaningful participation of girls and young women in United Nations processes and intergovernmental decision-making, facilitating intergenerational discussions on women’s leadership, promoting the integration of a gender perspective into youth inclusion and youth-led action and by promoting discussions on sexual and reproductive health and rights as an integral part of the youth agenda.

In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy and guided by Office’s research findings and recommendations on young people with disabilities, the Office will advocate for meaningful participation of young persons with disabilities in the work of the United Nations and beyond. In consultation with young people with disabilities and their networks and organizations, the Office will mainstream disability inclusion into all aspects of its work, with the aim of ensuring accessibility to opportunities, information and events, to the greatest extent possible.
Evaluation activities
The following evaluation conducted by the Office and completed in 2024 has guided the proposed programme plan for 2026:
(a) 	First interim review of Youth2030, the United Nation Youth Strategy

In response to the results of the evaluation referenced above, the Office coordinated the envisioning of the second phase of the youth strategy, together with the Youth2030 Joint Working Group towards establishing strategic priorities for the second phase of implementation of the Strategy (2025-2030).
Programme performance in 2024
Youth engagement advanced at the Summit of the Future

On 20 September 2024, the Youth Action Day at the Summit of the Future highlighted young people’s leadership in driving global commitments and translating the Pact for the Future into action. Convened by the Office in collaboration with UN entities, civil society, and youth networks, the event engaged 2,447 registered participants under the age of 30, making it the largest youth gathering in United Nations history. Anchored in Chapter IV of the Pact for the Future, and the Declaration on Future Generations, the event amplified youth voices, fostered intergenerational dialogue, and strengthened accountability for commitments. It culminated in a Youth Action Day Outcome Document outlining over 20 recommendations across three principles: inclusion, equity, and trust; and six key themes: gender equality, technology and digital infrastructure, intergenerational solidarity and equity; climate and environmental sustainability, governance and humanitarian action. These efforts positioned young people as co-creators in shaping global policy and the future.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 1.167).
Performance measure

table_content.text: Significant advancement towards mainstreaming meaningful youth participation in policymaking and decision-making spaces at all levels reflected in the Pact for the Future

children.text: Planned results for 2026

Result 1: strengthened system-wide action for and with young people to address their needs, amplify their voices and advance their meaningful engagement – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

The Office’s work contributed to 41 per cent of United Nations country teams and 59 per cent of United Nations entities achieving a “green” performance rating for at least 80 per cent of all key performance indicators in the United Nations Youth Strategy scorecard in 2024, which did not meet the planned target of 80 per cent for 2024. The targets were not met owing to gaps in integrating the youth agenda into United Nations strategic frameworks and a lack of institutional mechanisms for tracking youth-related investments.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 1.XXXVIII).

Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

The Office’s work contributed to young people, United Nations entities and Member States participating in consultations on key principles for meaningful youth engagement in the context of the Summit of the Future, which met the planned target.

children.text: Result 3: towards a Global Youth Investment Platform to scale up youth-related programming – Proposed programme plan for 2026

Member States, in the Pact for the Future (RES/79/1), stressed the importance of investing in, and ensuring equitable access to, essential services for all children and young people to advance their social and economic development. To fulfil their full potential and secure decent, productive work and quality employment, young people must have access to safe, inclusive, equitable and quality education opportunities, including in emergencies, throughout their lives that equip them with the knowledge, skills and capabilities they need to thrive in a rapidly changing world.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the Office was the need to strengthen access to sustainable and coordinated financing for youth-focused and youth-led initiatives. In applying the lesson, the Office will work towards the establishment of a Global Youth Investment Platform to attract and better finance youth-related programming at the country-level, in line with paragraph 60 (a) of the Pact for the Future. The Platform will aim to address funding gaps, strengthen coordination, and ensure investments are inclusive, equitable, and aligned with youth needs. The Office will engage in system-wide consultations to develop the concept for the Platform, and options for its operationalization, for the consideration of Member States.

text: XV.			Office of Data Protection and Privacy

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Office of Data Protection and Privacy was established pursuant to General Assembly resolution 78/252 as an independent office responsible for assisting the Secretariat in ensuring respect for data protection and privacy in the use and processing of personal data by Secretariat entities, consistent with United Nations mandates. The right to privacy in contemporary international law is enshrined in multiple international frameworks, including article 12 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and article 17 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The Assembly has continued to consider this issue actively, including through its resolution 77/211 and preceding resolutions, by which it reaffirmed the right to privacy in the digital age, and its resolution 78/265, in which it advocates for the safeguard of privacy and the protection of personal data as part of promoting safe, secure and trustworthy artificial intelligence systems.

In furtherance of relevant resolutions and decisions of the General Assembly, the Secretary-General promulgated a bulletin by which he established a data protection and privacy policy for the Secretariat (ST/SGB/2024/3). The Office contributes to the effective implementation of data protection and privacy standards, in line with that policy, and to fostering a culture of data protection and privacy awareness across the Secretariat.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which the Office contributes, is to ensure that, when personal data are processed by United Nations Secretariat entities, such processing is consistent with United Nations mandates and in a manner that respects the rights of individuals and groups.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Office will:

(a) 	Provide independent and impartial advice and support to the Secretary-General and United Nations Secretariat entities on the measures to be taken to ensure compliance with the data protection and privacy rules, regulations, processes and policies of the Secretariat;

(b)	Provide assistance to entities, for example, to fulfil requests made by individuals about their personal data to ensure implementation and compliance with relevant data protection and privacy rules, regulations, processes and policies in relation to personal data that are shared across entities, including through Secretariat-wide enterprise systems, or that otherwise relate to several entities;
(c)	Establish and maintain a reporting mechanism for receiving and disseminating requests made by individuals about their personal data;
(d)	Monitor and report to the Secretary-General on compliance with data protection and privacy rules, regulations, processes and policies of the Secretariat;
(e)	Foster a culture of data protection and privacy awareness across the Organization.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	A workplace culture that recognizes the importance of data protection and privacy across the Secretariat;
(b)	Effective prevention, identification and mitigation of data protection and privacy risks across the Organization;
(c)	Increased transparency and accountability in the Organization’s data protection and privacy practices.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following assumptions:
(a)	United Nations Secretariat entities adopt data protection and privacy standards, in line with the data protection and privacy policy;
(b)	United Nations Secretariat entities build dedicated capacity to ensure that personal data are processed appropriately and respect the rights of individuals and groups.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Office will participate in inter-agency networks, as appropriate, to share best practices and advance common practices for data protection and privacy system-wide.

The Office integrates a gender perspective into its operational activities, deliverables and results. The Office will identify any systemic issues concerning gender inequality in the Organization’s operations as regards data protection and privacy aspects. The Office will also provide gender statistics, where relevant and appropriate.

In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the Office will ensure that it takes into account the needs of persons with disabilities, both in the accessibility of its services and in its support for the implementation of the data protection and privacy requirements within the Organization. The Office will, in particular, work to ensure that any relevant content, including information conveyed online such as through privacy notices and forms, contains accessibility features that benefit persons with disabilities.
Programme performance in 2024
Advanced the protection of personal data and privacy standards at the United Nations Secretariat through promulgation of an overarching data protection and privacy policy

Ensuring responsible use of personal data within the Organization is a priority of the Secretary-General. In March 2024, following the establishment of the Office of Data Protection and Privacy pursuant to General Assembly resolution 78/252, the Secretary-General promulgated a bulletin establishing an overarching data protection and privacy policy for the Secretariat of the United Nations (ST/SGB/2024/3). This policy represents a significant milestone in data protection and privacy at the United Nations Secretariat as it strengthens the Organization’s approaches to data protection and privacy, aligning them with international best practices, while also addressing the 2021 recommendation of the Board of Auditors to expedite the development of a comprehensive data protection and privacy policy (A/77/5 (Vol. I)). The promulgation of this policy is also integral to the Organization’s broader efforts to achieve a more agile, responsive, and resilient United Nations, as referenced in the Pact for the Future (A/Res/79/1 para. 73).
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 1.178).
Performance measure

children.text: Result 2: Optimized business processes to integrate data protection and privacy compliance across the Organization – Programme plan for 2026

While promulgation of the data protection and privacy policy for the Secretariat of the United Nations was a critical first step in strengthening the Organization’s approaches to data protection and privacy, ensuring effective data protection and privacy compliance remains a multi-dimensional endeavour, with implications across not only policy, but also business processes.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the Office was that effective implementation of the policy requires dedicated mechanisms to integrate data protection and privacy compliance within the Organization’s structure and business processes. In applying the lesson, the Office will establish strategic partnerships with key internal stakeholders, such as the Office of Information and Communications Technology, the Office of Legal Affairs, the Department of Management, Strategy, Policy, and Compliance, and the Department of Operational Support, and oversee the revision of existing business processes and development of dedicated mechanisms to ensure effective and sustained data protection and privacy compliance across the Organization.
Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 1.180).
Performance measure

text: XVI.	Office of Digital and Emerging Technologies

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

In an age of increasing digital interdependence, the General Assembly has long recognised that effective cooperation on technology issues is an indispensable component of addressing new challenges and opportunities of an increasing digitalised world, inter alia in resolutions 56/183, 70/1, 70/125, 75/1, 78/132 and 78/160 including as a key driver for the 2030 Agenda. The position of Envoy on Technology was established in 2021 to advise the senior leadership of the United Nations on key trends in technology, so as to guide the strategic approach taken by the Organization on such issues, to serve as an advocate and focal point for digital cooperation so that Member States, the technology industry, civil society and other stakeholders would have a first port of call for the broader United Nations system, and to facilitate multi-stakeholder policy dialogue on emerging technologies (see A/74/821). The establishment of the Office of the Secretary-General’s Envoy on Technology was noted by the General Assembly in its resolution 75/316.

Through the adoption of resolution 79/1 annex I “Global Digital Compact”, the General Assembly requested the Secretary-General, following consultations with Member States, to submit a proposal to the General Assembly for the establishment of an office, building on and incorporating the existing activities and resources of the existing Office of the Secretary-General’s Envoy on Technology, to facilitate system-wide coordination, working closely with existing mechanisms. Through its resolution 79/258, the General Assembly approved the establishment of the Office for Digital and Emerging Technologies and its operational functions.
Programme of work
Objective
The objective, to which the Office contributes, is to ensure that cooperation on technology governance is advanced for a better future.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Office will:
(a)	Advise the senior leadership of the United Nations on key trends in technology, so as to guide the strategic approach taken by the Organization on such issues;
(b)	Serve as advocate and focal point for digital cooperation, through engagement with Member States, the technology industry, civil society and other stakeholders;
(c)	Facilitate multi-stakeholder policy dialogue on digital and emerging technology issues;
(d)	Strengthen system-wide coordination within and across the United Nations system on digital and emerging technology issues;
(e)	Support the follow-up and implementation of the Global Digital Compact.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	More inclusive and effective cooperation at all levels on digital and emerging technology issues;
(b)	Strengthened coherence within and across the United Nations system on digital and emerging technology issues;
(c)	Enhanced implementation of the Global Digital Compact.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following assumptions:
(a)	Member States continue to engage in constructive dialogue and cooperation on digital and emerging technology issues at the global and regional levels;
(b)	Adequate extrabudgetary resources are available to ensure meaningful engagement across the United Nations system, as well as national, regional and global institutions and organizations.

With regard to cooperation with other entities at the global, regional, national and local levels, the Office will collaborate with global and regional organizations such as the World Bank, African Union, European Union and OECD. The Office will also prioritize the forging of new relationships and the strengthening of existing ones with relevant civil society organizations, academia and the private sector.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Office will strengthen system-wide coordination within and across the United Nations system on digital and emerging technology issues, serving to promote collective synergies and messaging on such issues and more effective use of resources across the United Nations system.  This includes serving as Co-Chair of the Working Group on Digital Technologies with ITU, facilitating more frequent, intensive engagement and systematic follow-up on joint efforts and strengthening coordination within and between the implementation of the Global Digital Compact and WSIS+20, as well as other United Nations processes, such as the Multistakeholder Forum on Science, Technology and Innovation for the SDGs, as well as with the UN Technology Bank for the Least Developed Countries. The Office will continue to partner with and connect other UN System and non-UN entities through joint programming in service of the Office’s objective. The Office will also step up engagement with Regional Economic Commissions, the Development Coordination Office and the resident coordinator system to provide guidance on best practices regarding digital transformation for use by Member States, and for connecting to regional, national and local networks in support of implementation of the Global Digital Compact.

The Office integrates a gender perspective into its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate, including by advocating for the meaningful participation of girls and young women in relevant United Nations processes, and by incorporating a gender perspective on digital and emerging technology issues in multi-stakeholder policy dialogues facilitated by the Office.

In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the Office will advocate for the meaningful participation of persons with disabilities in relevant United Nations processes, and by incorporating perspectives of persons with disabilities on digital and emerging technology issues in multi-stakeholder policy dialogues facilitated by the Office. The Office will aim to ensure accessibility for persons with disabilities to information and events produced by the Office, to the greatest extent possible.
Result 1: strengthened multistakeholder commitment to the Global Digital Compact – Proposed programme plan for 2026

In 2024, at the Summit of the Future, the General Assembly adopted the Global Digital Compact, which serves as a comprehensive global framework for digital cooperation with the goal of an inclusive, open, sustainable, fair, safe and secure digital future for all. The Office has encouraged and enabled international and regional organizations, the private sector, academia, the technical community and civil society groups to engage actively in the Compact’s implementation. These actions will broaden and deepen efforts to realize the Compact’s objectives, with voluntary endorsements serving as an indicator of the extent of stakeholder alignment with the Compact’s vision and commitments through the High-level review of the Global Digital Compact during the 82nd session of the General Assembly.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the Office was that endorsement modalities require continuous stakeholder engagement and thorough vetting, which can be resource intensive. Following the Summit of the Future and the adoption of the Global Digital Compact, the Office swiftly established an endorsement modality in accordance with paragraph 66 of the Global Digital Compact. Through open calls to international and regional organizations, the private sector, academia, the technical community and civil society groups, the platform quickly generated significant traction. However, due to the open nature, each submission requires careful vetting, placing a considerable demand on available resources. In applying the lesson, the Office will adapt the endorsement modality to generate less burden, such as through semi-automated filtering and improved internal processes and workflows.
Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 1.XLI)
Performance measure: number of endorsements of the Global Digital Compact (cumulative)

text: XVII. United Nations Alliance of Civilizations

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The United Nations Alliance of Civilizations (UNAOC) was established in 2005, as an initiative of the Secretary-General, to explore the root causes of polarization within and between societies and to recommend a programme of action, including through the promotion of intercultural and interreligious dialogue to build bridges of understanding. UNAOC aims to foster understanding and cooperation across cultures and religions and to counter polarization and extremism.

The General Assembly, through its resolutions 64/14 and 69/312, expressed its support for the work of UNAOC and reiterated its valuable role in promoting greater understanding and respect among civilizations, cultures, religions and beliefs.

In its resolution 78/264, the General Assembly requested the Secretary-General to appoint a United Nations Special Envoy to combat Islamophobia. Subsequently, in its resolution 79/258 B, the Assembly approved the conversion of the post of High Representative for UNAOC (Under-Secretary-General), previously funded from extrabudgetary resources, to regular budget funding under UNAOC under section 1. The post would serve a dual role as High Representative for the United Nations Alliance of Civilizations and the United Nations Special Envoy to Combat Islamophobia.
Programme of work
Objective
The objective, to which UNAOC contributes, is to improve understanding and cooperation among nations and peoples across cultures and religions and to reduce polarization at local and global levels.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, UNAOC will:
(a)	Promote interreligious and intercultural dialogue, including dialogue among civilisations;

(b) 	Design and implement peace education initiatives that equip young people with the critical thinking skills and competencies needed to play an active and positive role in issues of peace and security and in preventing violent extremism and radicalization;

(c)	Provide grant funding mechanism, capacity-building support and mentorship to young people, and civil society organisations implementing projects related to  intercultural and interfaith dialogue, particularly in areas affected by identity-based conflict, combat intolerance and stereotyping based on religion or belief;

(d)    Facilitate dialogues to build stronger partnerships and promote the voices of young people and of civil society at large, including faith actors and grassroots organizations, fostering mutual understanding and collaboration across divides;

(e)	Reinforce synergies with international organisations that work for the integration of migrant communities and promote the role of municipalities and cities in building inclusive and resilient societies;

(f)	Develop initiatives that train young people in multimedia storytelling and video production and facilitate collaborative media projects that unite young creators from different cultural and religious backgrounds, emphasising the creation of content that changes the narrative around migrants and promotes tolerance, respect, dialogue and cooperation;

(g)	Promote the role and contribution of women as peace mediators, including through its Women’s Alliance for Peace initiative and through intercultural and interreligious mediation training aimed at women leaders in conflict contexts;
(h)   Identify, showcase and promote the role of religious leaders and faith-based organizations engaged in interreligious mediation;
(i)  Develop, support and participate in global communication, advocacy and programming initiatives that amplify the message of inclusion and peace through sports;

(j)     Collaborate with arts institutions, cultural organisations and educational institutions to integrate arts into broader advocacy efforts aimed at promoting tolerance, respect, dialogue and cooperation.

(k)	Engage with United Nations entities for a comprehensive and coordinated approach to addressing and responding to Islamophobia, antisemitism and other forms of intolerance based on religion and belief;

(l)	Conduct briefings for Member States to highlight the nexus between religious intolerance and human rights, and to contribute to efforts towards the effective development of system-wide responses to all forms of religious intolerance;

(m)	Organise tailored institutional events focusing on trends in Islamophobia to provide a platform for a multi-stakeholder approach, including Member States, relevant United Nations entities, media providers, civil society and faith actors, in combating Islamophobia;
(n)	Engage in dialogue on Islamophobia with State and non-State actors, in order to address the root causes, explore possible solutions and good practices to address Islamophobia;

(o) 	Engage with Member States and relevant stakeholders to assist, as appropriate, in the implementation of the recommendations contained in the United Nations Plan of Action to Safeguard Religious Sites, including, carrying out of the #Forsafeworship communication campaign, raising awareness of the international community and public at large about the universality of religious sites, issuance of press statements in condemnation of attacks on worshippers, acts of violence, attacks and destruction on and in religious places, sites and shrines, which are in violation of international law, in both conflict and non-conflict situations;

(p)   Engage with the United Nations relevant entities and agencies on the implementation of the recommendations contained in the United Nations Action Plan to Enhance Monitoring and Response to Antisemitism, including the convening of relevant stakeholders (Member States, regional and international organizations, Jewish organizations and communities) to explore good practices to respond to antisemitism.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Enhanced social stability and an environment conducive to peace and mutual understanding;
(b)	Advancement of intercultural and interreligious dialogue, and a culture of peace and mutual respect;
(c)	Improved action by Member States and non-state actors to address the root causes of all forms of religious intolerance, xenophobia and discrimination based on religion, belief or ethnicity.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)   Governments have the political commitment and dedicate resources to accelerate action to prevent conflicts and address the root causes of all forms of religious intolerance;
(b)   Civil society, faith-based organizations, local communities, the private sector and media are committed to working together to advance intercultural and interreligious dialogue;
(c)   Personnel, at all levels, prioritize addressing all forms of religious intolerance within United Nations operations;

With regard to cooperation with other entities at the global, regional national and local levels, UNAOC will continue to garner support of Member States for the advancement of intercultural and interreligious dialogue, culture of peace and mutual respect; and the reinforcement of partnerships with regional and sub-regional actors for the practical implementation of its activities, including with the European Union, the League of Arab States, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, the Organization of American States, Council of Europe, the Organization of the Black Sea Economic Cooperation, Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, International Organization of Turkic Culture and Union for the Mediterranean. In addition, UNAOC will also continue to work closely with non-State actors, namely, civil society, youth, local communities, faith actors academia, media, research institutes and the private sector to build capacity and raise awareness of the role of intercultural and interreligious dialogue in conflict prevention and addressing the root causes of all forms of religious intolerance, xenophobia and discrimination based on religion, belief or ethnicity.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, UNAOC will continue to co-chair the Inter-agency Network on Religion and Sustainable Development and engage the multi-faith advisory council to the network; act as vice-chair of the Working Group on Preventing and Countering Violent Extremism; and lead the establishment and the activities of the United Nations Monitoring and Evaluation Working Group to monitor, evaluate and assess the impact of policies and measures to address antisemitism on a regular basis. In addition, the UNAOC will continue to strengthen its cooperation with the Department of Global Communications, Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs, International Organization for Migration, United Nations Population Fund, United Nations Office of Counter-Terrorism, United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, Office of the Special Adviser on the Prevention of Genocide, Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, United Nations Youth Office and the Special Rapporteur on freedom of religion or belief of the United Nations Human Rights Council, through information exchange, joint events and initiatives, for a more effective advocacy and coordinated actions to ensure the prevention agenda remains prominent on the international agenda and to address all forms of religious intolerance in a coherent manner within the United Nations system.

UNAOC integrates a gender perspective into its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. In 2026, UNAOC will continue to support the Women’s Alliance of Peace and promote the inclusion of women peace mediators in conflict mediation and conflict resolution initiatives. UNAOC will continue advocacy for the voices of young women and men that support peace processes on the local levels to be more actively represented at the global events of UNAOC and other relevant forums. Information on UNAOC programmes’ beneficiaries will continue to be systematically disaggregated by sex in order to present a gender-sensitive analysis of UNAOC programme impact.

In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, UNAOC will seek to increase accessibility of its core documents and capacity-building training materials for persons with disabilities, to the extent possible.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced ownership of Member States to promote a culture of peace, interreligious and intercultural dialogue for mutual understanding

In November 2024, the host Government of Portugal and UNAOC delivered the 10th Global Forum of UNAOC in Cascais, Portugal, with the in-person participation of 118 official delegations of Member States and international organizations and over 1,200 partners from civil society, state, academia, private sector, media, religious leaders, faith actors and general public. The event featured a Youth Forum with over 128 young leaders from more than 70 countries; two plenary sessions and 9 thematic panels; special segments such as the Intercultural Innovation Hub and the PLURAL+ Youth Video Festival ceremonies. A special side event entitled “One Humanity Match for Peace and Inclusion” brought together celebrated athletes, global leaders, and youth to highlight the transformative power of sports as a platform for promoting peace, tolerance, respect, dialogue and cooperation among different cultures, civilizations and peoples. At the Forum, the community of the UNAOC Group of Friends adopted by consensus the Cascais political declaration, marking the UNAOC achievements over the past 20 years. In the declaration, Member States emphasised the need to combat all forms of religious intolerance and acknowledged the central role of inclusive, quality and transformative education in promoting dialogue, peace and human rights.

In 2024, UNAOC also commemorated the International Day of Human Fraternity in partnership with the Permanent Missions of Egypt and the United Arab Emirates. UNAOC was also one of the leading substantive partners and co-organisers of the 6th World Forum on Intercultural Dialogue, hosted by Azerbaijan, and convened a plenary session on the interfaith dialogue as a confidence-building measure.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 1.197).
Performance measure

table_content.text:
4 Member States hosted international forums to promote a culture of peace; 
118 Member States and international organizations adopted a political declaration in support of UNAOC and its values and principles

children.text: Planned results for 2026
Result 1: Increased awareness about contemporary trends in Islamophobia among state and non-state actors – Proposed programme plan for 2026

In its resolution 78/264, the General Assembly expressed concern at the growing manifestations of intolerance based on religion or belief and emphasized the importance of respect for religious and cultural diversity, as well as as well as interreligious, interfaith and intercultural dialogue aimed at promoting a culture of tolerance and respect among individuals, societies and nations. In the same resolution, the Assembly requested the Secretary-General to appoint a United Nations Special Envoy to combat Islamophobia. In line with Assembly resolution 79/258 B, the post of High Representative for UNAOC will serve a dual role as High Representative for the United Nations Alliance of Civilizations and the United Nations Special Envoy to Combat Islamophobia.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for UNAOC was the need for a strategic framework to guide the work of the United Nations on combating Islamophobia. In applying the lesson, the High Representative for UNAOC and United Nations Special Envoy to combat Islamophobia, will develop the United Nations Action Plan to Combat Islamophobia, which will contain recommendations and a call for action for Member States, civil society and public at large. UNAOC will establish a consultative process on root causes and good practices in combating contemporary forms of Islamophobia, and will engage with a wide range of stakeholders, including relevant United Nations entities and coordinators, Member States, regional organizations, and civil society actors, with a view to developing the Action Plan. The Action Plan and its implementation thereof will enable coordinated, system-wide efforts towards combating Islamophobia and promoting a culture of tolerance and respect.
Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 1.198).
Performance measure

text: XVIII. 				Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Future Generations

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Future Generations would provide leadership and coordination across the United Nations System on the capacities, activities, and programmes required to support Member States in their efforts to implement the Declaration on Future Generations, approved by the General Assembly as an annex to the Pact for the Future on 22 September 2024 (resolution 79/1).

The Declaration on Future Generations reaffirms earlier commitments to the purposes and principles of the Charter of the United Nations, to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, as well as to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, to the political declaration of the Sustainable Development Goals Summit of 2023 and to the Rio Declaration on Environment and Development.

The Declaration sets out the foundations to safeguard the needs and interests of future generations through concrete measures and follow-up mechanisms. In the Declaration, future generations are defined as all those generations that do not yet exist, and who will inherit this planet. It includes a commitment by Heads of State and Government to “equipping the multilateral system, including the United Nations, to support States, upon their request, in their efforts to implement this Declaration and embed the needs and interests of future generations and long-term thinking in policymaking processes by fostering cooperation and facilitating greater use of anticipatory planning and foresight, based on science, data and statistics, and raising awareness of and advising on the likely intergenerational or future impacts of policies and programmes” (para.30) and “fostering an organizational culture that is future-oriented and mainstreamed across the United Nations system in order to facilitate science- and evidence-based decision-making by developing diverse capabilities, including anticipatory planning, foresight and futures literacy, and systematically promoting long-term and intergenerational thinking at all levels.” (para. 31). It also comprises a decision to “convene an inclusive high-level plenary meeting of the General Assembly on future generations that will review the implementation of this Declaration during the eighty-third session of the General Assembly and provide updates on the actions taken to safeguard the needs and interests of future generations” and a request to the Secretary-General to “present a report on the implementation of this Declaration for consideration at the high-level plenary meeting to be held during the eighty-third session of the General Assembly” (para. 32).

The Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Future Generations will provide leadership and coordination across the United Nations System to meet the demands on the United Nations System deriving from this Declaration.

The Special Envoy will serve as a voice for long-term thinking and future generations at the global level, and would advocate, including in intergovernmental processes, high-level events and fora, for present generations to act responsibly to safeguard the needs and interests of future generations.

The Special Envoy will be responsible for developing a vision to fulfil the commitments of the Declaration on Future Generations and set strategic goals and objectives for its implementation. This will involve offering support and advice to Member States and providing leadership and policy guidance to the United Nations system on activities meant to accelerate the implementation of the Declaration, including through a better use of science, data, anticipatory planning, strategic foresight and futures literacy. The Special Envoy will also lead the preparations of the report of the Secretary-General on the implementation of the Declaration for consideration at the high-level plenary meeting to be held during the eighty-third session of the General Assembly in September 2028 and support Member States with the preparatory work, organization and execution of the high-level plenary meeting to be held during the eighty-third session of the General Assembly in September 2028.

Other changes

1.432	As reflected in tables 1.210 and 1.211, resource changes reflect an increase of $1,062,800 owing to the proposed conversion of three posts (1 USG, 1 P-3 and General Service (Other level)) funded from extrabudgetary resources and the establishment of two posts (1 P-5 and 1 P-2/1) as part of the effort to meet the demands on the United Nations System deriving from the Declaration on Future Generations.
1.433	The functions of the Envoy would include the following:
(a)	Developing a shared vision to fulfil the commitments of the Declaration on Future Generations and set strategic goals and objectives for its implementation;
(b)	Offering support to Member States, upon their request, in their efforts to develop long-term thinking in their policymaking processes;
(c)	Advising Member States, as appropriate and with the support of other United Nations entities, on mainstreaming future‐oriented considerations in UN documents being deliberated;

(d)	Providing leadership and policy guidance to the United Nations system on activities meant to accelerate the implementation of the Declaration on Future Generations, including by undertaking a system-wide approach for the assessment, development, implementation and evaluation of policies and programmes that safeguard the needs and interests of future generations;
(e)	Promoting a future-oriented culture across the United Nations system, including by supporting better use of science, data, anticipatory planning, strategic foresight and futures literacy;

(g)	Leading the preparations of the report of the Secretary-General on the implementation of the Declaration for consideration at the high-level plenary meeting to be held during the eighty-third session of the General Assembly in September 2028;

(h)	Supporting Member States with the preparatory work, organization and execution of the high-level plenary meeting to be held during the eighty-third session of the General Assembly in September 2028;

1.434	The increase of $1,062,800 includes an increase of $901,300 under posts, for the proposed conversion of three posts, comprising 1 USG (Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Future Generations), 1 P-3 (Programme Management Officer) and 1 General Service (Other level) (Administrative Assistant), and the establishment of two posts, 1 P-5 (Senior Programme Management Officer) and 1 P-2/1 (Associate Programme Management Officer) (see annex II to the present report).

1.435	The increase of $161,500 under non-posts reflects provisions of $81,900 under travel of staff for the participation of the Special Envoy and his team in meetings of UN bodies and consultations with organizations, institutions, specialized agencies and other stakeholders to discuss assessment, development, implementation and evaluation of policies and programmes that safeguard the needs and interests of future generations; $59,100 under contractual services to cover the organisation of a workshop and the development of a website; and $20,500 for related non-post resources to support the proposed conversion and establishment of posts.
1.436	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 1.213.

children.text: Summary of proposed changes in established and temporary posts, by component

table_content.text: Establishment of 1 post of Administrative Officer

The United Nations Independent Audit Advisory Committee plays a critical role in promoting transparency, accountability, and efficiency within the United Nations system. As the scope and complexity of its work have expanded, including additional reporting on the budget of OIOS and broader oversight responsibilities, the members of the Independent Audit Advisory Committee, at their sixty-eighth session held from 3 to 6 December 2024, endorsed the establishment of an Administrative Officer post to strengthen the operational capacity of the Committee. The Administrative Officer will provide essential support to manage the growing workload, ensuring the timely and diligent completion of tasks and safeguarding the high standards of the Committee’s work. The incumbent will also enhance continuity of operations by providing senior-level support and oversight in the absence of the Executive Secretary, thereby ensuring the stability and effectiveness of the Office in delivering on its increasing mandates.
Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Children and Armed Conflict
Establishment of 1 post of Data Specialist

In its resolution 79/257, the General Assembly reaffirmed that the Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Children and Armed Conflict should be provided with the necessary resources to effectively implement the mandate, including to ensure that the monitoring and reporting mechanism (MRM) collects and communicates accurate, objective, reliable and verifiable information. The MRM increasingly relies on robust data analysis to identify patterns, trends, and gaps in the six grave violations against children. From 2019 to 2024, the number of grave violations against children rose by 35 per cent (from over 24,000 to 32,990 cases), with data now monitored and reported in 26 situations. In this context, it is proposed to establish one post of Data Specialist (P-3) to enhance the MRM’s capacity to provide actionable insights and ensure the collection and communication of accurate, objective, reliable and verifiable information. The incumbent will complement the qualitative reporting by field teams with quantitative analysis to drive evidence-based advocacy, United Nations strategic decision-making and engagement to enhance child protection. In addition, the incumbent will also ensure coherence in data collection and reporting across United Nations entities in the field and provide guidance to entities such as UNESCO and WHO as they increase their mandate-specific monitoring.
Office for Digital and Emerging Technologies
Establishment of one Programme Management Officer

The proposed establishment would provide a regional presence of the Office within the regional economic commissions and serve as a vital interface with the Economic Commission for Africa (UNECA) and the regional presence of the Development Coordination Office. The incumbent, based in Addis Ababa, would source regional expertise into global digital cooperation processes, engage in relevant regional initiatives, and advise United Nations Resident Coordinators on their support to governments on digital and emerging technologies. This role is critical for supporting the implementation of the Global Digital Compact.
Establishment of one Programme Management Officer

The proposed establishment would provide a regional presence of the Office within the regional economic commissions and serve as a vital interface with the Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean (UNECLAC). The incumbent, based in Santiago, would source regional expertise into global digital cooperation processes, engage in relevant regional initiatives, and advise United Nations Resident Coordinators on their support to governments on digital and emerging technologies. This role is critical for supporting the implementation of the Global Digital Compact.
Establishment of one Programme Management Officer

The incumbent would contribute to United Nations system coordination on digital cooperation and emerging technologies and further strengthen the cooperation between Geneva-based and New York-based processes. The functions of the incumbent, based in Geneva, would include, inter alia, supporting United Nations system-wide coordination arrangements on digital and emerging technologies, including preparing for, organizing and following up on coordination exercises, drafting and synthesizing language inputs to develop common messaging and positions regarding technology issues, and contributing to United Nations system-wide information-sharing and reporting on the implementation of technology-related work.
Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Future Generations
Conversion of 1 post of Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Future Generations

The Special Envoy for Future Generations would serve as the senior advisor of the Secretary-General on issues related to the implementation of the Declaration on Future Generations, annexed to the Pact for the Future. The Special Envoy would fulfil leadership and coordination functions within the United Nations System, to ready the Organization to implement the Declaration, as mandated in its paragraphs 30 to 32.  The Special Envoy for Future Generations would lead in positioning the Future Generations agenda at the highest levels and offer support to Member States, upon their request, in their efforts to develop long-term thinking in policymaking processes and raise awareness of and advise on the likely intergenerational or future impacts of policies and programmes. The incumbent would advise Member States, as appropriate and with the support of other United Nations entities, on safeguarding the needs and interests of future generations, including through intergovernmental processes. The Special Envoy would also foster the cooperation of Member States and the UN system with stakeholders, including civil society, young people, academia, the scientific community and the private sector, and encourage intergenerational partnerships and whole-of-society approaches to develop innovative, long-term and forward-thinking policies and programmes. The Special Envoy would lead preparations of the report on the implementation of the Declaration for consideration at the high-level plenary meeting during the eighty-third session of the General Assembly in September 2028, and support Member States with the preparatory work, organization and execution of the meeting.
Establishment of 1 post of Senior Programme Management Officer

The Senior Programme Management Officer would lead the development and implementation of the programme of work of the Office of the Special Envoy for Future Generations, providing leadership and coordination within the United Nations System by steering the UN’s contribution to the implementation of the Declaration on Future Generations.  The incumbent would provide leadership for the development of analytical tools and policy recommendations on the likely intergenerational or future impacts of policies and programmes, and on safeguarding the needs and interests of future generations including through intergovernmental processes; provide substantive advice for the engagements of the Special Envoy with Member States and stakeholders and represent the Special Envoy as needed; guide and coordinate the drafting process related to the preparations of the report on the implementation of the Declaration for consideration at the high-level plenary meeting during the eighty-third session of the General Assembly in September 2028; and coordinate the preparatory work, organization and execution of the high-level plenary meeting. The responsibilities of the Senior Programme Management Officer would also include the coordination of United Nations outreach to Member States and stakeholders on matters related to the implementation of the Declaration on Future Generations. The incumbent will provide overall team leadership for the day-to-day management of the Special Envoy’s Office, clarify expectations and desired results, monitor and oversee progress of individual team member’s work, provide guidance and take timely action to ensure delivery and achievement of the team’s objectives.
Conversion of 1 post of Programme Management Officer

The Programme Management Officer would directly support the Special Envoy for Future Generation’s work and function as the Envoy’s Special Assistant. Under the supervision of a Senior Programme Management Officer, and with the support of relevant UN entities, the incumbent would support the development and refinement of analytical tools and policy recommendations on the likely intergenerational or future impacts of policies and programmes, and on mainstreaming future‐oriented language in documents being negotiated and adopted in intergovernmental fora, for the consideration of Member States. The incumbent would also provide support to the engagements of the Special Envoy with Member States and stakeholders, including civil society, young people, academia, the scientific community and the private sector; assist in drafting and coordinating inputs from the UN system for  the report on the implementation of the Declaration for consideration at the high-level plenary meeting during the eighty-third session of the General Assembly in September 2028; and support the preparatory work, organization and execution of the meeting.
Establishment of 1 post of Associate Programme Management Officer

The Associate Programme Management Officer would directly support the Special Envoy’s work on the implementation of the Declaration on Future Generations, annexed to the Pact for the Future, as mandated in its paragraphs 30 to 32. Under the supervision of a Senior Programme Management Officer, and with the support of relevant UN entities, the incumbent would contribute, through research and analysis, to the development of analytical tools and policy recommendations on the likely intergenerational or future impacts of policies and programmes, and on mainstreaming future‐oriented language in documents being negotiated and adopted in intergovernmental fora, for the consideration of Member States. The incumbent would also provide logistical support to the engagements of the Special Envoy with Member States and stakeholders, including civil society, academia, the scientific community and the private sector and support the Special Envoy in the preparatory work, organization and execution of the high-level plenary meeting during the eighty-third session of the General Assembly in September 2028 and perform logistical and administrative tasks as required.
Conversion of 1 post of Administrative Assistant

The incumbent would provide administrative support to the Special Envoy for Future Generations and to the office in the discharge of their work in support of the UN system implementation of the Declaration on Future Generations, in relation to Action 30, 31 and 32 of the Declaration.  The incumbent would be responsible, inter alia, for drafting routine correspondence, providing protocol support to meetings and conferences, arranging travel, and performing other administrative duties as required.
